Vector Operations (Dot, Cross, Projectio.description: Operations involving vectors in three-dimensional space, including calculating dot products, cross products, and projecting one vector onto another. These are fundamental tools in vector calculus and physics.

Lines and Planes.description: Study of equations that define lines and planes in 3D space. Involves finding the parametric equation of a line, and normal vectors to planes, and determining intersections or angles between planes.

3D Shapes.description: Exploration of three-dimensional geometric shapes like spheres, cylinders, and cones, including how to describe their properties using equations in 3D space.

Vector Functions.description: Functions that output vectors, particularly as a function of time or a parameter. Applications include the study of curves in space, and finding derivatives and integrals of vector-valued functions.

Velocity, Speed, Acceleration.description: Understanding motion through vector functions, focusing on velocity as the derivative of position, speed as the magnitude of velocity, and acceleration as the derivative of velocity.
Further exploration of motion in space, using vector functions to describe and analyze velocity, speed, and acceleration over time.

Partial Derivatives and Tangent Planes.description: The concept of partial derivatives applied to multivariable functions, and using these to find equations of tangent planes to surfaces at a point.

Optimization.description: Techniques for finding maximum and minimum values of functions with several variables, including the use of Lagrange multipliers for constrained optimization problems.

Double Integrals.description: Techniques for evaluating double integrals, both in Cartesian and polar coordinates, to calculate areas and volumes over regions in the plane or space.

Application of Double Integrals.description: Using double integrals in practical applications, including calculating areas, volumes, and average values, as well as in physics for mass and moment calculations.

Centre of Mass.description: Finding the center of mass for an object using double integrals, by integrating mass distributions over a region or a volume.
